author: rwieruch
full_text:
👀 Feature-Based React Architecture

In a growing application, it's easy for different domains to become intertwined.

For example, in the UI, a Comment component can quickly end up inside a Post component, and a data-fetching function might be extended beyond its original https://t.co/krr7GxCZIJ
note_tweet_text:
👀 Feature-Based React Architecture

In a growing application, it's easy for different domains to become intertwined.

For example, in the UI, a Comment component can quickly end up inside a Post component, and a data-fetching function might be extended beyond its original purpose.

This often happens in larger projects, where you'll encounter descriptive data-fetching functions like getPostWithAuthor() or getPostWithComments().

Here, I'll demonstrate how I typically decouple domains in React using a feature-based architecture:

1⃣ Identify cases where domains are intertwined in your UI or business logic.

2⃣ Break down large, multi-purpose query functions into smaller, domain-focused query functions.

3⃣ Separate components from different domains by placing them in their dedicated feature folders. Let each component handle its own data fetching.

At this point, you encounter waterfall requests ...

4⃣ Lift components and their data fetching higher up the hierarchy to avoid nesting components. This nesting often occurs when database relationships are projected directly onto the UI.

5⃣ Shift from parallel to sequential data fetching to improve the performance.

And that's it! You've successfully decoupled your domains across different layers of your application (e.g., UI layer, API layer) while maintaining better structure and ensuring performance isn't compromised.

We are learning this approach in The Road to Next 🔥 Closing in 24 hours.
cognitive_value: Enables React maintainability with feature-based architecture

author: kevinkern
full_text:
Bolt:

Bolt is an awesome tool I use it since day 1. You can quickly build your own specs in GPT/claude and fire it at bolt. You will get really good results. The team behind Bolt is also super fast at adding new features and improvements.

If you need to start a lot of projects https://t.co/ipKQOy8AcN
note_tweet_text:
Bolt:

Bolt is an awesome tool I use it since day 1. You can quickly build your own specs in GPT/claude and fire it at bolt. You will get really good results. The team behind Bolt is also super fast at adding new features and improvements.

If you need to start a lot of projects like doing demos or building multiple apps in a month then bolt is a viable tool.

But if you're working on an existing codebase, keep in mind that it’s mostly a generator right now. At some point, you might hit a wall.

They’ve added helpful features like "Lock" and "Target File," but as someone coding 8 hours a day, you’ll need more consistency to keep things smooth.

Also, Bolt and v0 work better with React than for example with some other framework like Nuxt/Vue. I’ve tested the same app repeatedly, and it always ran into issues with Nuxt. So, Vue/Nuxt support isn’t quite there yet, which also applies to most code generators.

Deployments: Netlify Prefered
X Accounts: stackblitz
cognitive_value: Enables rapid prototyping with Bolt AI development tool

author: nurijanian

Customer interviews are what made me stand out as a PM. But it took me 18 months to master JTBD theory. In 1 minute, I'll teach you what took me 18 months.

1. Stop asking about solutions
Instead ask: "What were you trying to accomplish?"

2. Focus on timeline
"Walk me through
note_tweet_text:
Customer interviews are what made me stand out as a PM. But it took me 18 months to master JTBD theory. In 1 minute, I'll teach you what took me 18 months.

1. Stop asking about solutions
Instead ask: "What were you trying to accomplish?"

2. Focus on timeline
"Walk me through the day you decided to make a change"

3. Hunt for emotions
"What was frustrating about your previous approach?"

4. Document verbatim
Actual quotes > your interpretations

5. Look for patterns
4-5 interviews saying the same thing > 20 random data points

I've done hundreds of interviews this way. It's not a foolproof way to ship good products, but you reduce the risk of failure with this.

The uncomfortable truth: Most PMs do "customer interviews" but just validate their existing ideas.

Real insights come from shutting up and listening.

(I have 100+ proven interview questions saved in https://t.co/ngCnvp77SD if you want to get started)
cognitive_value: Enables customer discovery with JTBD interview theory in 1 minute

author: jCircle9
note_tweet_text:
I don’t know if these are underutilized, but I got a list of “ah ha” moments / tricks learned over the years

1. Search Anything in the DevTools

•Use Ctrl+Shift+P (Cmd+Shift+P on Mac) to bring up the command menu. This works as a search bar for any feature in DevTools. For example:
•Type “screenshot” to capture screenshots directly.
•Type “show rulers” to toggle rulers.

2. CSS Debugging with Forced States

•Right-click an element → Force State → Apply :hover, :focus, or :active to simulate states without needing to interact with the UI.

3. $$ Shortcut for DOM Queries

•In the Console:
•$$('selector') works like document.querySelectorAll to quickly grab elements.
•$0 accesses the last-selected element in the Elements panel.
•$1, $2, etc., access previously selected elements.

4. Log DOM Changes

•Right-click an element → Break on… → Select “Subtree Modifications” to pause execution whenever the DOM changes for that element.

5. Copy as JavaScript Snippet

•Right-click a DOM element → Copy → Copy JS path to copy the document.querySelector code for that element.

6. Color Picker and Eyedropper

•Inspect an element → Click on its color property to open the color picker.
•Use the eyedropper tool to sample any color on your screen.

7. Monitor Events

•In the Console, use monitorEvents(element, 'eventType') to log when a specific event occurs, e.g.:

monitorEvents(document.body, 'click');

8. Performance Insights with Lighthouse

•Use the Lighthouse tab for generating performance audits and insights directly within the DevTools.

9. CSS Grid and Flexbox Overlays

•In the Elements tab, look for grid and flexbox containers. Click the icon next to them to toggle overlays, making debugging layouts much easier.

10. Track Layout Changes with Paint Flashing

•In the Rendering tab (accessible via Ctrl+Shift+P → “Show Rendering”), enable Paint Flashing to visualize which areas of the screen are being repainted.

11. Emulate Slow Networks or CPUs

•Go to the Performance tab → Click the Settings → Adjust network throttling or CPU throttling to test under constrained conditions.

12. Instant JavaScript Execution

•Select text in the Console or in the Sources panel, right-click, and choose Evaluate in Console to run it directly.

13. Copy Network Requests as fetch

•Open the Network tab, right-click any request → Copy → Copy as fetch to get a ready-to-use JavaScript snippet.

14. Block Specific URLs

•In the Network tab, right-click a request → Block request URL to simulate missing or blocked resources.

15. Replay User Flows

•In Chrome’s Recorder panel, you can record a series of interactions, save them, and replay for debugging flows like logins or checkout.

16. Console Table Display

•Use console.table() to display arrays or objects as neat, sortable tables:

console.table([{name: 'Alice', age: 30}, {name: 'Bob', age: 25}]);

17. CSS Animations Playback

•In the Animations tab, you can scrub through animations frame-by-frame or adjust playback speed.

18. Inspect HTTP Headers

•In the Network tab, click on any request, then go to the Headers tab to view request and response headers.

19. Debug Async Call Stacks

•Open the Call Stack panel and enable Async mode to trace asynchronous JavaScript calls more easily.

20. Record Screenshots for UI/Animation Debugging

•In the Performance tab, click the camera icon before starting a recording to capture a frame-by-frame breakdown.
cognitive_value: Enables DevTools mastery with Ctrl+Shift+P command palette

Great for coding Landing pages and micro saas (4-5 pages)

After Replit introduced React + Vite. It is now building applications with cool UI. 

Still a bit slow. A bit over complicated 

BUT moving in right direction.

Best in their domain:
Cursor - For coding
V0 - For frontend design

Half baked projects:

Windsurf IDE - 4/10
Disappointed with the output. It was breaking after 5th step every time.

Still need improvement:

GPTengineer - 4/10
Cool idea but competition is now super tough.

Bolt is moving at crazy pace. v0 improved context with context caching.

GPTengineer is still implementing 1 edit in one message. 

Here's my tech stack as of today.

I use ChatGPT search for research
I use o1 model for documentation
I use v0 for frontend design
I use claude AI for coding brain
I use cursor for code implementation
I use replit to deploy projects

I feel like I can build any web app now with this stack in 5-7 days.

I'll be sharing some cool experiments in coming days.

Stay tuned.

author: nurijanian
full_text:
Stop treating engineering estimates like prophecies.

Start treating them like conversations.

Here's how:

1. Instead of asking "How long will this take?"
Ask "What makes this complex?"

2. Instead of pushing for faster delivery
Ask "What could make this simpler?"

3. Instead of
note_tweet_text:
Stop treating engineering estimates like prophecies.

Start treating them like conversations.

Here's how:

1. Instead of asking "How long will this take?"
Ask "What makes this complex?"

2. Instead of pushing for faster delivery
Ask "What could make this simpler?"

3. Instead of accepting the first estimate
Ask "What would change if we had half the time?"

4. Instead of diving into solutions
Ask "What are we assuming about the problem?"

5. Instead of fighting over story points
Ask "What could go wrong?"

The goal isn't to get faster estimates.

It's to build shared understanding that removes the cruft and builds sustainable velocity.
cognitive_value: Enables estimation culture with conversational approach

author: gregisenberg
full_text:
consumer mobile apps are quietly back thanks to tiktok creators and AI 

if i wanted to make $1M with mobile apps right now, here’s the exact playbook i’d use:

1. find hidden opportunities on sensor tower.

search for apps making $30k+ monthly with basic or outdated AI, or
note_tweet_text:
consumer mobile apps are quietly back thanks to tiktok creators and AI 

if i wanted to make $1M with mobile apps right now, here’s the exact playbook i’d use:

1. find hidden opportunities on sensor tower.

search for apps making $30k+ monthly with basic or outdated AI, or non-AI apps that could use an AI edge. 

pick ones with clunky UI or weak UX—those are your goldmines. improve the look, add useful AI, and you’re on your way.

2. master one distribution channel. 

pick your niche’s top platform and lock into one format that works. post daily, and use claude to analyze the best posts in that space. figure out the language that drives engagement.

3. scale distribution through tiktok creators.

search tiktok shop hashtags in your niche + "link in bio" 

find sellers doing $10k+ monthly in physical products look for 40k+ followers and high engagement rates bonus if they're already promoting other apps

the big insight here is way easier to sell $4.99 app to a stranger than a $49 pillow to a stranger.

DM strategy that works: "saw you crushing it with [product]. we're building an app that solves [same problem] at $4.99. most users stick around 6+ months. 50% rev share on every sale you drive. interested in early access?"

start everyone on 50% rev share track performance for 90 days convert your top 3 to equity milestone-based vesting tied to revenue

4. launch quick, effective landing pages.

v0 for mockups, get inspiration from top app store screenshots, and set up a waitlist + a simple validation survey. throw ~$50 into tiktok ads to see if your copy converts before committing resources.

5. keep the build stack lean

 v0 for UI, claude for code, openai for AI features, and revenue cat for payments. minimize overhead so you can iterate fast and keep costs low.

6. scale and rinse

launch a related app and cross-promote with the first one. bundle pricing to lock users in and reuse your creator network to scale even faster.

congratulations, you didn’t just build an app—you built a mobile holding company.

seeing this playbook work again and again

last month saw a holdco

2 founders 
3 apps
0 VCs
15 creators on the cap table
72% margins
$120k/month in combined revenue
not based in silicon valley

it fires me up.
cognitive_value: Enables mobile app business with TikTok+AI playbook

note_tweet_text:
If you want to truly learn Operating System and build a rock-solid foundation in CS, this book is a must👇👇

1. Comprehensive Coverage – Every OS concept is explained in-depth.
2. Clear Fundamentals – Builds a strong base for OS theory and practice.
3. Real-World Examples – Learn through practical, real-world scenarios.
4. In-Depth Process Management – Master scheduling, concurrency, and threads.
5. Memory Management Mastery – Dive deep into paging, segmentation, and virtual memory.
6. File Systems & Storage – Understand how data is managed and retrieved efficiently.
7. Synchronization & Deadlocks – Critical concepts explained with clarity.
8. Security and Protection – Learn how modern OS ensures safety and security.
9. Networking and Distributed Systems – Gain insights into OS-level networking.
10. Perfect for Deep Learning – Essential for anyone serious about OS at an advanced level.
11. I highly recommend this for anyone aiming to master Operating Systems!
cognitive_value: Enables OS fundamentals with comprehensive book

author: NikkiSiapno
full_text:
Tokenization explained.

Tokenization is a security technique that replaces sensitive information with unique placeholder values called tokens.

By tokenizing your sensitive data, you can protect them from unauthorized access and lessen the impact of data breaches. Tokenization https://t.co/ggYQOMoBER
note_tweet_text:
Tokenization explained.

Tokenization is a security technique that replaces sensitive information with unique placeholder values called tokens.

By tokenizing your sensitive data, you can protect them from unauthorized access and lessen the impact of data breaches. Tokenization also lets you scale back on security measures in other areas of the system.

Tokenization process:

Sensitive data is sent to a tokenization service when it enters the system. There, a unique token is generated, and both the sensitive data and the token are kept in a secure database known as a token vault.

For extra protection, the sensitive data is generally encrypted within the secure data storage. The token is then used in place of the sensitive data within the system and third-party integrations.

Detokenization process:

When an authorized service requires sensitive data, it sends a request to the tokenization service that contains the token. The tokenization service validates that the requester has all the required permissions. If it does, it uses the token to get the sensitive data from the token vault and returns it to the authorized service.

Tokenization is useful for more than just protecting sensitive data. It also helps simplify the rest of the system, because you don't need to worry about additional security measures in components that handle a token instead of sensitive data.
